Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2011 12:26PM epgnyc wrote: You don't say what chemo you are on.  I had no terrible taste problems when I was receiving AC (4xDD), although there were quite a few foods that tasted a bit odd....mostly meat of any type.  That being said, I was nauseous the entire 9 weeks I was on AC, despite every type of anti-nausea drug they could throw at me, so the issue of taste was moot.  But once I started on Taxol (again 4xDD), I got this hideous chemical taste in my mouth and there was nothing that would get rid of it except for sucking on hard candies.  But since one can't spend 18 hours a day sucking on hard candies, this was hardly a solution.  The good news was that the bad taste improved for me with each succeeding Taxol treatment and wasn't bad at all for the remaining 5-6 weeks of Taxol chemo.  Good luck with it!
Posts.Title: Horrible Taste Lingering! Carla9112 NannaBaby

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2011 11:01AM epgnyc wrote: I had my mammo/us on a Wed.  I'd already known there was something hinky, although there was no lump and my PS agreed.  They did extra mammo images and after all the tests were done, the radiologist came in and said she didn't know what was going on either, but I needed a biopsy.  I had the biopsy the following Thurs. and was glad I didn't have to wait longer as waiting is often the hardest part.  And the very next day my surgeon called to say it was breast cancer....again (this was my 2nd time having it). Hoping there's nothing "spectacular" and, for that matter, nothing whatsoever to be concerned about.  Please try not to worry alot (so easy to say) and enjoy your holidays.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: How long did you wait between mammo and biopsy? Dawnsigkap Tenmom

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2012 09:30AM epgnyc wrote: Last year I had a 2nd diagnosis of TNBC in my left breast and since over the years I'd had several biopsies in the right breast as well, I decided to have a BMX this time around (I had a lumpectomy the first time).  I too was afraid my BS might give me some grief for wanting to do both, but she was fine with it.  Many women choose a BMX for symmetry reasons and I do hear it's easier to achieve that by having both done at once.  I chose no reconstruction so that wasn't a factor for me.  I wanted a prophelactic MX on the right breast to give myself peace of mind.  With my history I felt it was a ticking time bomb!  I also had an bilateral oopherectomy, but that was done separately in 2002 at the same time as I had a re-excision of my lumpectomy.  I doubt the surgeon would want to do a BMX and an oppherectomy all at once.  But good luck with the meeting with your surgeon.  My prediction is that you'll get the okay.
Posts.Title: Anyone's BCS refuse a BMX? 7of9 itsjustme10

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 10:45AM epgnyc wrote: Hi, Tappy.  I was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer for the 2nd time in Feb. (1st time was in 2002).  Since we with TNBC can't take any of the hormonal drugs, chemo is very important for us.  I was given a regimen of 4 AC and 4 Taxol, dose dense.  This was preceded by a bi-lateral mastectomy in March.  I was told I'd be out for 6 weeks following that, but I went back to work half days after 4 weeks.  I went back full-time after 6 weeks, and this schedule was very workable for me.  I started chemo 6 weeks after my mastectomies. I work for a small financial services company (staff of 10) and everyone was very supportive.  We have to dress professionally but it was summer so I could dress slightly less formally than during the winter months.  I had to wear a wig too (hats or scarves would not have been acceptable).  I'd get your wig before your 2nd chemo treatment as that's when the hair starts to fall out.  I had my head shaved right at the point it started to fall out.  It's now 6 months after my mastectomies and 6 weeks after the end of chemo and I'm still wearing my wig and will be for several more months.  So get something you like and is comfortable as you'll be wearing for awhile. I had my chemo treatments on Thurs. and so took off Thurs. and Fridays after the first couple of treatments (early on I took only the Thurs. off).  I worked throughout my chemo but left at 3 p.m. each day without taking a lunch hour, giving my a 6-hour workday.  This worked well for me.  And even though I had a terrible time with SE's (constant nausea despite all the new meds, several hospitalizations because of zero white blood count, skin rashes, allergies to Taxol, neuropathy, terrible fatigue, etc.), I continued to work throughout.  It kept my sane and gave me something to think about besides the stupid cancer.  It also helped me to feel a bit more like myself.  I might not have been at my peak work-wise, but I could certainly do my job.  But clearly It would not have been possible to work if I had to travel for my job or be an air traffic controller or something like that.  I really depends on the nature of your job. The fatigue was probably the worst of it and I had friends do some of my grocery shopping for me.  I also asked a couple of my friends who like to cook make me a bunch of meals I could freeze and reheat.  Living in New York City, I also took car service and taxis to and from work every day as the subways were too much for me physically.  It was a splurge financially but well worth it.  Besides I wasn't spending money on anything else (except for medical care of course).  I used whatever energy I had doing my cancer treatments and going to work....there really wasn't any energy left for anything else.  It was possible because of my situation too -- I'm single.  With personal support and a supportive workplace, I think working throughout chemo is definitely doable....and even preferable.  But that's just my opinion.  You'll do whatever you decide is best for you.  Best of luck to you!  Ellen
Posts.Title: Chemo and working TAPPY TAPPY

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 11:06AM epgnyc wrote: I was diagnosed with TNC 9 years ago and used Dr. Alexandra Heerdt at Memorial Sloan-Kettering as my surgeon and loved her!  I am talking about serious, serious love here.  Unfortunately I was rediagnosed in February, again with TNC in the same left breast and this time she performed a bi-lateral mastectomy.  I've been seeing my surgeon, Dr. Heerdt, and my oncologist, Dr. Mark Robson, during all the intervening 9 years for follow-ups and so my team was entirely in place this time.  I can't say enough about Dr. Heerdt.  Not only is she an excellent surgeon, she is also a very caring person (not something one gets or expects often in a surgeon of any type).  She's extremely intelligent, will never let you wait when she has test results (she has called me from vacation!) and you can ask as many questions as you want -- she's very patient.  I can't imagine having any other breast surgeon and hope you will be seeing her and that I'm not too last with this post.
Posts.Title: NYC surgeons sara1970 Hortense

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 11:57AM epgnyc wrote: Plant Lover, My only nephew went through very much the same thing when he 16-17.  He too was in treatment and on medication but the anxiety worsened to the point where he was no longer able to attend school.  He completed his last year of high school through alternate and on-line programs.  We were all so worried about him and ultimately how this would affect his life and future job opportunities.  I am happy to report my nephew is now in his 20's and is Asst. Branch Manager at a JPMorgan Chase Bank in Connecticut. While I completely understand your concerns about this young person, please take heart.  These programs can be a god-send for students like these.  Good luck to all of you.
Posts.Title: Teen Struggling in School PlantLover 1Athena1

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2012 07:53PM epgnyc wrote: I'm the Director of HR for my company and handle all the medical and dental insurance plans.  An HMO is the type of a plan that means you can only see the doctors or hospitals that are in what is called your health plan's "network."  These are doctors and hospitals that have struck special deals with that insurance company.  If you were to go outside of these to see a particular specialist or visit a hospital not in your network, there would be no medical coverge extended.  Also your primary care physcian (regular doctor) will have to refer you to see any specialists or other doctors, e.g. oncologists, breast surgeons, etc. I have no experience with Kaiser Permanente since I live and work on the East Coast, but I have heard some good and some bad about them.  If I were you, when your husband's company has it's annual enrollment period, he may be able to choose a different health plan, for instance a PPO or POS plan, which would give you much more choice and flexibility in your medical care.  Keep in mind, that what a health insurance company deems to be "medically necessary" isn't necessarily the same thing that your doctors think is medically necessary.  As to the issue of caps, many policies no longer have caps on medical benefits.  You should check your plan. Good luck.  Hope your treatment goes smoothly and seamlessly with Kaiser.
Posts.Title: health insurance questions kebab epgnyc

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2011 02:43PM epgnyc wrote: Hi, Kennylynne.  I am 3 months post-treatment now (AC+T) and my eyebrows are back about 75% and my eyelashes about 40%.  But they're coming!  My hair on the other hand is only about 1" long and has turned almost completely silver (used to be about 50/50).  And I don't think you're vain at all.  No doubt you'd just like to reclaim part of your old life.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Hair loss and regrowth kennylynne hakeemshahnawazanddoctors

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 02:07PM epgnyc wrote: Hi, Seemz. Sorry you're going through all this worry.  I used to suffer from pain in both breasts, though mostly in one.  I was finally told by my radiologist that caffeine can cause breast pain, especially when one has fibrocystic breasts as I do (they're also dense).  After our conversation I stopped drinking caffeine and all the pain went away.  It has been years since I gave up my full-jolt coffee in the morning and I don't regret it al all.  It's difficult enough feeling a lumpy area much less having pain in one's breast.  Give it a try -- it could help and it certainly won't hurt.
Posts.Title: When should I back off? seemz epgnyc

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2011 07:01AM epgnyc wrote: I have no good suggestions for you.  I am completely phobic about needles myself.  Literally I had to go to a hypnotherapist in order to be able to receive my chemo infusions (didn't want a port).  The hypnotherapy worked for that but not well enough to enable me to give myself the shots.  The first time (I first had BC 9 years ago) I had a friend give me the Neupogen shots, which I only needed a few of, and the 2nd time (I had a BC recurrence earlier this year) I received Neulasta injections instead.  This time I went to the cancer center once every 2 weeks and the nurse gave me the shot.  This worked extremely well for me since I live only 11 blocks from the center (I live in NY City). I was in and out in 5 minutes. Can't you just tell your husband to man up?  Otherwise I think going in and having them do the injection is a good solution....as long as you're not too far away.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Neupogen shots etherize llm005

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2012 02:37PM epgnyc wrote: I'm Director of HR for my firm and it doesn't make any difference how long the paperwork takes, you will be covered through COBRA under your insurance plan from the date insurance was lost (if you enroll in COBRA with 60 days).  The only snag is that technically you are dropped and then reistated back to the date coverage was lost once the paperwork is processed.  You won't owe anything in the long run but you may have to pay out of pocket and then get reimbursed once the insurance has been processed by the carrier.  But for treatment through a hospital, by the time the hospital bills your for anything, you will have been reinstated.  If it were me, I'd keep your appointment and carry on as normal.  Sorry about your husband's job but please don't worry about the insurance.  You'll have full, seamless coverage if you sign up for COBRA within 60 days.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Just lost our insurance mthomp2020 epgnyc

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2011 01:58PM epgnyc wrote: Hi, Marlee. I had a BMX back in March (one on the BC side and the other prophylactic, like you).  This was my 2nd bout with triple negative BC (the first time was in 2002, in the same breast).  I don't want to have to deal with this again so opted for a bilateral mastectomy.  I'm a young 63 and was pretty sure that I didn't want any reconstruction.  I've had way too much surgery (also had a bilateral oopherectomy in 2002) and like you, I just want to get on with my life.  I also saw a BS just to review my options in case I changed my mind about reconstruction and found out that in any event I was not a candidate for implants because of prior radiation and my skin's bad reaction to it.  So that left me with DIEP flap surgery and another 6 weeks of recovery.  No thank you!  It's now almost 7 months since my BMX and I'm very happy with my decision.  I have full range of motion back and now that I've finished chemo it's only upward and onward from here.  Good luck with your decision....it sounds like you have a very positive attitude.
Posts.Title: No reconstruction- Happy w/your decision? marlee1 quietpools

Posts.Content: epgnyc wrote: Has anyone else broken out in a terrible, itchy rash all over their body?  It started fairly innocuously 2 weeks ago a week after my 2nd AC treatment and yesterday went in to see my oncologist about my upcoming 4th treatment, it was a little scary looking.  My oncologist called it "impressive."  They sent me to see one of the hospital's dermatologist's to see if I'm okay to have my chemo as scheduled and I finally got the okay (yea - I just want to be finished with the Red Devil).  But I fear it will get worse before it gets better.  Anyone else out there experience this and if so, how long did it take to go away?  Thanks. Dx 5/2002, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Dx 2/4/2011, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Rashes epgnyc starbeauty

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 03:42PM epgnyc wrote: I'm so sorry you have to go through this.  That being said, mastecomy isn't so terrible.  I've had breast cancer twice, 9 years apart, and had a lumpectomy the first time and bilateral mastectomy the 2nd time. I do think you should speak with you doctor though about having a sentinel node biopsy.  This is extremely common in the U.S. but maybe less so in the U.K.  The usual procedure here was to have the sentinel node biopsy where they only take between 1 - 3 nodes.  These are then tested to see if they are cancerous (this is usually done the day of and during surgery) and then if any are, they would go back in at the time of surgery and take lots more.  But a recent study came out showing that they don't even have to do that any more.  Having only the sentinel node(s) taken will greatly improve your recovery so it's worth discussing.  Wishing you luck with your upcoming procedures.  We've all been there and you're doing fine. Ellen
